history.content:
Hey! I got a B- in 61A, but I didn't let that faze me. I had to get my act together if I was to declare. I spent my winter break doing Hilfinger's old homework assignments, reading Head First Java, and doing the labs. I was able to get half the semester's work done. I installed IntelliJ ahead of time also. When midterm 1 came along, I scored above average. Unlike my experience in 61A, I didn't find 61B terribly difficult because I exposed myself to the material ahead of time, and up to midterm 2 I was on the trajectory to an A.

However, as the pandemic hit and the material I didn't study for approached, I seriously started struggling. It got to the point where I didn't have time to allocate to the class because I had to move and help my family file for unemployment and get household supplies. I didn't finish Gitlet and dropped today, so I'm taking 61B this fall. Had I finished Gitlet, I would've earned an A- without taking the final.

I plan on doing the same thing and studying the material from midterm 2 but this time doing the projects for exposure and practice. If you're not working this summer, there should be enough time for you to finish the course. You can find Hug's old material here. Feel free to do it, since it's publicly available–even to non-Berkeley students.

children.subject:
Hello,

I got a B+ in 61A despite spending hours and hours studying, doing almost all the practice midterms/finals, etc. Yet I still was not able to succeed and get the grade I wanted. I am trying to put this behind me and move forward. I know I have a strong work ethic but unfortunately, it was not enough to succeed in this class. I know you said that those two were your lowest CS grades you received. I would love it if you could give me advice about how you changed your studying habits (or what you did differently in general) in order to succeed in future courses. 

Thank you in advance!

That sounds great to be honest! Keep going at it and you will realize that some people stopped trying as hard especially past the first three classes you need to declare. Also, a lot of people might be doing well now since they've had a couple of years of experience in the past. However, once their advantage run out, your work ethic and attitude will likely carry you forward while they've got to learn to cope with the fact that they are no longer ahead of the others and slowly adapt to this change. 

1. Reading and thinking through slides >>> watching webcasts after you have already gone to lecture. 

So previously I used to spend a lot of time just watching webcasts over and over again, however, I've learned that after you've gone to lecture, you should only watch webcasts on parts you know you definitely need help on, and save yourself a lot of wasted time by going through the slides on your own pace and think through all of them. Active learning is much greater than passive learning, as it requires much more engagement.

2. Think through everything and try to explain each design choice, concept, or essence fo the question in one or two sentences.

This really helps, try to break seemingly complex concepts into simple and intuitive explanations.

3. Do exam problems once you have a good (not excellent) understanding of the course material.

Same logic, active > inactive learning.

4. Get into teaching!

Try to get into CSM and eventually course staff for courses you are passionate about! Seeing things from the other side help to understand how to learn better in the future. 

Good luck

Hey, to the student response above, really really appreciate your positive attitude. You will achieve whatever you set your mind on for sure!

I had sort of a similar experience, B in 61A and B+ in 61B despite trying super hard. I was extremely disappointed in myself but I never gave up. Fast forward and I’m now a graduating senior. I’m proud to say that those were the two lowest CS classes in terms of grades I’ve ever scored (I’ve taken at least ten of them). 

One thing I’ve learned is that the struggle now will really set you up for success in the future, and your attitude and work ethics will eventually outlast whatever head start others might have. Good luck, rooting for you!

I got a B+ in 61A and an A in 61B (with Hug).

For me, what helped was really understanding the labs – for doing well in 61B as well as in technical interviews, really understanding each lab (not just passing the autograder) was of utmost importance, and I felt that it helped me become an expert on data structures. 

Of course, past exams problems, CSM, talking about your progress, etc are all super helpful as well. But I think really understanding labs, projects, and homework assignments were super useful in that class.

history.content: I got a B+ in 61A, and I really really want to get an A in 61B in the fall. Does anyone have any advice for preparing for Hug's class? I'll have some free time over the summer and want to come in prepared.
history.subject: Preparing for 61B
